Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.time_to_resolution: Approximately 6-12 months (IPEDS Fall 2025 enrollment data and NCES Digest typically released mid to late 2026; Caplan likely to comment soon after official data release.)
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Higher Education Policy Analysis (with a focus on IPEDS Enrollment Data Monitoring), I bring direct familiarity with the data definitions, reporting cycles, historical enrollment trends, recent policy changes, and how shocks (domestic and international) affect 18-24-year-old enrollment rates in 4-year institutions. I understand the mechanics of how the IPEDS and NCES data are collected and reported, and can contextualize recent news about international enrollment, visa policy, and demographic shifts within historical base rates and reporting practices.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.status_quo: If nothing changes, the enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in 4-year colleges would continue its slow decline from the 2015 peak (29.9%), but would likely remain above the 26.6% threshold by 2025. Historically, the rate has declined by less than 0.3 percentage points per year, even with recent headwinds.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sharp 2025 decline in international student enrollment (especially new entrants, down 17%)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. International students are a non-trivial part of 4-year college enrollment, and the 2025 visa crisis is the largest acute shock to new international undergrad enrollment since 9/11 or COVID-19, occurring during the main admissions cycle.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Long-term demographic decline of U.S. 18-24-year-olds (the 'enrollment cliff')
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The U.S. high school graduate population has been shrinking, leading to fewer domestic first-time students, especially after 2023.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Increased admissions accessibility (one-click applications, direct admission, test-optional policies)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are aggressively lowering barriers to entry, waiving fees, and extending offers to offset declining demand, which boosts enrollment margins, particularly among marginal students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Colleges' financial desperation and price discounting
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Institutions have strong incentives to fill seats and are using scholarships and aid to maintain enrollment, especially at 4-year institutions.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Negative perceptions of college ROI and cost (especially for non-STEM fields)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Growing skepticism about the value of a degree may push some students to alternatives (workforce, trades, gap years), especially as student debt and weak labor market returns get more media attention.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Impact of Trump administration visa and funding policies in 2025
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The return of harder-line policy (suspended interviews, higher denials, stricter vetting) has had a clear chilling effect on international new enrollment, and federal funding cuts may indirectly reduce institutional capacity.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate of historical change (enrollment rates decline slowly, large step changes are rare)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Unless a shock is large and sustained, the enrollment rate rarely falls more than 1-1.5 percentage points in a single year, and the 10% drop threshold (to 26.6%) is a steep hurdle.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.no_scenario: The combined effect of a sharp, unprecedented 17% drop in new international undergrad enrollment, a continued domestic enrollment cliff, and a spike in negative sentiment about college value causes total 18-24-year-old enrollment in 4-year colleges to drop precipitously. The NCES Digest data for 2025 shows the rate at or below 26.6%, and Caplan loses the bet.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.yes_scenario: Despite the international enrollment collapse, colleges successfully boost domestic enrollment through aggressive admissions reforms, price discounting, and outreach to marginal students. The overall decline in the 18-24-year-old population is partially offset by increases in non-traditional and transfer enrollment, and the net effect is a rate above 26.6% (e.g., 27.2%). The rate continues its slow decline but does not breach the 10% drop threshold, and Caplan wins.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (IPEDS.final_reasoning: Base rates strongly favor Caplan, as the 18-24-year-old 4-year college enrollment rate has historically declined slowly, rarely dropping more than 1 percentage point per year. However, 2025 saw a unique, acute shock to international enrollment (down 17% for new students), which is well above the normal fluctuation and comes on top of ongoing domestic demographic decline. Still, international students make up only about 5% (all ages, all levels) of 4-year college enrollment, and the sharp decline in new entrants will only partially impact the total 2025 headcount, as many international students already in the U.S. remain enrolled. Aggressive domestic recruitment and loosened admissions standards are likely to blunt, but not fully offset, the overall decline. Given these offsetting factors, the most likely scenario is that the 2025 rate falls, but only to the 27–27.5% range—narrowly above Caplan's 26.6% threshold. The risk of a 'step-change' drop below 26.6% is significantly higher than in previous years (I estimate 15–25% chance), but the base rate and institutional incentives to maintain numbers keep the probability of Caplan winning above 70%.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.time_to_resolution: Approximately 1 year (2025 data will likely be released mid-to-late 2026, but the effective measurement year is about to close).
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postsecondary Access Policy), I bring a nuanced understanding of how both domestic and international policy, macroeconomic trends, and institutional strategies affect college enrollment rates. My focus on access policies allows me to assess the sensitivity of enrollment rates to changes in admissions practices, visa policies, demographics, and public perceptions.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.status_quo: The status quo is that the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in 4-year colleges has hovered near 29-30% in the mid-2010s, declining modestly to about 28% by the early 2020s. Historically, the annual change is gradual, with sharp drops usually associated with major economic or policy shocks (e.g., COVID-19, severe immigration restrictions). The base rate for a >10% drop in a decade (to below 26.6%) is low.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sharp drop in new international student enrollment (2025: -17% new, -1% overall)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. International students, though a minority of total undergraduates, are overrepresented in 4-year institutions and concentrated in the 18-24 age bracket. A 17% drop in new international students for fall 2025, following a 7% drop the prior year, poses a significant headwind for total enrollment.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic demographic cliff (declining number of 18-year-olds)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The shrinking pool of high school graduates, which began in the early 2020s and is accelerating, puts structural downward pressure on enrollment rates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Aggressive institutional mitigation strategies (easier admissions, fee waivers, direct admission, extended deadlines)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are pulling every lever—waiving fees, offering automatic admissions, extending deadlines, and lowering standards—to keep seats filled. These tactics can temporarily offset demographic and international losses.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public skepticism/value of college and price sensitivity
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Only 22% of Americans believe a degree is worth it if loans are required, and high sticker prices with uncertain ROI are deterring marginal students from enrolling at 4-year institutions.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal funding cuts and institutional financial strain
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Cuts of $7-8B in federal research and institutional support in 2025 constrict resources, which may force some less-resilient schools to cut programs or close, reducing capacity.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Post-pandemic bounceback and expanded access initiatives
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Test-optional policies, expanded financial aid, and streamlined applications have supported recent stabilization in domestic enrollment among 4-year colleges.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Lagging effect of prior higher international enrollments (OPT, graduate and doctoral students)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. While new international enrollment plummeted, total international enrollment is buttressed by continued growth in OPT and longer stays, slightly mitigating the immediate impact.

Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.no_scenario: International student inflow collapses beyond expectations due to visa/immigration chaos, the demographic cliff accelerates, and even aggressive admissions reforms cannot offset the losses. The enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in 4-year colleges falls sharply, dipping below 26.6% in the 2025 NCES data. This could be exacerbated by an economic downturn, further policy shocks, or major institutional closures.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.yes_scenario: Despite the sharp decline in new international students and a shrinking domestic student pool, colleges' aggressive recruitment and admissions reforms (easier applications, more aid, rolling deadlines, test-optional policies) successfully stabilize or only modestly reduce enrollment. The rate remains above 26.6%—possibly in the 27-28% range—due to institutional adaptation, a lagged effect from prior international enrollments, and a base rate tendency for slow change.
Higher Education Policy Analysis (Postse.final_reasoning: The sharp, sudden drop in new international student enrollment (-17% in 2025, -7% in 2024), driven by visa and policy turmoil, is a serious threat—international students are a non-trivial share of 4-year undergraduate enrollment and an even larger share of graduate enrollment (though the latter is not included in the 18-24 undergrad metric). The demographic headwinds from a shrinking population of 18-year-olds add to the pressure. However, the U.S. college enrollment rate—especially in 4-year institutions—has historically been sticky, with declines usually gradual except during acute shocks (e.g., COVID-19). The base rate for a >10% decade-over-decade drop is low. Institutional responses—waiving fees, easier admissions, direct offers—are unprecedented and likely to cushion losses among domestic students. The overall international student stock is less affected than the new cohort, due to OPT and longer graduate stays, but the 18-24-year-old undergrad metric is more sensitive to the new intake. Given that the most recent NCES Digest data (2023) showed enrollment rates for 18-24-year-olds at 4-year colleges still above 27%, and that the cumulative impact of all factors is likely to push the rate down but not catastrophically so, the most likely outcome is a modest drop, not a sharp collapse. Therefore, while the risk is higher than in past years, the probability that the rate remains above 26.6% (Caplan wins) is still the favored outcome, though not by a landslide.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.time_to_resolution: Approximately 12 months until NCES 2025 data publication and Caplan's public statement (expected in late 2026, covering the 2025 academic year).
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.perspective_relevance: As a demographic analyst using the cohort component method, I specialize in modeling population flows by age cohort and status, including educational enrollment. This perspective allows me to dissect the drivers of college enrollment rates—birth cohort sizes, domestic/international student flows, policy changes, and economic factors—providing a granular, historically grounded assessment of the likely trajectory for the 18-24-year-old enrollment rate in four-year colleges.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.status_quo: The rate in 2015 was 29.9%. In recent years, college enrollment rates among 18-24-year-olds have trended downward but remained above the 26.6% threshold through 2023, per NCES Digest data. The status quo, absent severe shocks, is a slow decline due to demographic headwinds and changing attitudes toward higher education.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic high school graduate cohort size
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly decreases probability. The number of 18-year-olds is flat-to-shrinking due to prior birth rate declines, exerting downward pressure on the denominator and absolute enrollments.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International student enrollment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. News reports a catastrophic breakdown in U.S. student visa processing in 2025, with a 17% decline in new international undergraduate enrollment and up to 50% drops among Indian students. As international students are a meaningful part of the 4-year college population, this likely pulls the overall rate down.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional behavior (admissions standards and recruitment)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly increases probability. Colleges are responding to shrinking pools by loosening admissions standards, offering direct admission, and waiving fees, potentially propping up enrollment rates among domestic students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Public perception of degree value
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately decreases probability. Only 22% of Americans now believe a degree is worth the cost if financed by loans, likely depressing domestic demand.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal policy and funding
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mildly decreases probability. The Trump administration's 2025 funding cuts and hardline immigration stance (visa restrictions) further reduce enrollment, especially among international students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate/historical momentum
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability. The historical pace of change in enrollment rates is slow. The drop needed to fall below 26.6% is steep (~11% drop from 2015, or a further 1-2 percentage points from recent levels), which would be historically rapid.

Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.no_scenario: The enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges falls to 26.6% or below in the 2025 NCES data. This would require the combined effect of a sharp drop in new international students (due to visa failures and policy), ongoing demographic shrinkage, weak domestic demand, and an inability of colleges to offset these losses through recruitment or admissions relaxation. The international student collapse proves large enough, and domestic demand soft enough, to tip the rate below the threshold.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.yes_scenario: The enrollment rate remains above 26.6% in 2025. Despite the international student shock, domestic enrollment proves more robust than feared due to aggressive institutional outreach, expanded financial aid, and relaxed admissions. The denominator (total 18-24-year-old population) may shrink enough to partially offset numerator losses. The overall rate only dips slightly from the most recent levels (~27.5% in 2023), staying above the bet's threshold.
Demographic Analysis (Cohort Component M.final_reasoning: The base rate for this type of sharp, sudden enrollment drop is low. Historically, the 18-24 college enrollment rate moves slowly. However, the news presents a significant negative shock: a 17% drop in new international undergraduate enrollment (with even sharper drops for key countries), and a 17% overall drop in new international students. Since international students make up a disproportionate share in certain institutions but a moderate proportion overall, the effect on the aggregate 18-24-year-old enrollment rate is meaningful but not catastrophic. Domestic colleges are responding by further easing admissions, but public skepticism regarding degree value and funding cuts are headwinds. The key question is whether the international student shortfall, coupled with demographic and attitudinal headwinds, is enough to drive the rate down by more than a full percentage point from 2023 (approx. 27.5%). Given the large international shock, but the stickiness of overall enrollment rates and the likelihood that domestic students partially offset the loss, I judge that the probability Caplan wins (rate stays above 26.6%) is a bit below even odds—slightly favoring a 'No,' but not extremely so due to the inertia of such metrics. I estimate a 40% chance that Caplan wins his bet.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.time_to_resolution: Approximately 1 year (the question resolves when the 2025 enrollment data is published, likely late 2026, but the relevant enrollment snapshot is Fall 2025; today is December 25, 2025).
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.perspective_relevance: As a demographic analyst specializing in population projection standards, my expertise is in understanding enrollment trends, age-cohort projections, and the impact of demographic, economic, and policy shocks on the college-going population. This is directly relevant for interpreting the magnitude and timing of shifts in college enrollment rates, especially among 18-24-year-olds, and for contextualizing recent data in historical perspective.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.status_quo: The status quo, as of 2015, was a 29.9% enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds in four-year colleges. The 10-year trend prior to the pandemic was generally stable or modestly declining. The bet will be won by Caplan if the 2025 figure is above 26.6%. If nothing changed demographically or in policy, the rate would likely remain just under 30%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International Student Enrollment Collapse (2024-25)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent news describes a 17% drop in new international student enrollment for Fall 2025 due to catastrophic visa processing failures, following a 7% drop the prior year, and a 44% drop in Indian student arrivals from July-August 2025. International students disproportionately attend four-year institutions, so this is a significant negative shock.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic Demographic Headwinds (Declining 18-24 Population)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The number of high school graduates is shrinking, and the cohort of 18-24-year-olds is plateauing or declining, which puts downward pressure on absolute enrollment, even if participation rates are stable.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Declining Domestic Demand / Value Proposition
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Surveys show declining perceived value of a degree (22% of Americans think a degree is worth it if it requires loans), and there is a broader trend of skepticism toward college. This is likely to suppress the enrollment rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional Countermeasures and Lower Admissions Barriers
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are responding vigorously: waiving application fees, offering automatic admissions, dropping test requirements, and extending recruitment timelines. These efforts are designed to prop up enrollment rates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal and State Policy Shocks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Recent federal funding cuts, stricter visa/immigration policies, and regulatory uncertainty increase headwinds for four-year colleges.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base Rate / Status Quo Bias
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Large, abrupt drops in aggregate four-year college enrollment rates (for the whole 18-24 population) are historically rare outside of severe recessions or policy shocks. The rate declined from a peak of about 33% in 2010 to 29.9% in 2015, and likely only gradually since. A drop below 26.6% in ten years would require an unusually sharp, persistent decline.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Timing of Data Collection and Potential Recovery
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Some visa processing improvements occurred late in 2025, but likely too late for Fall 2025 enrollment; however, if institutions managed to offset losses with domestic recruitment or deferred international admissions, the hit might be blunted.

Demographic Analysis (Population Project.no_scenario: The Fall 2025 NCES data reports that the four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds is 26.6% or less. This could happen if: (a) the international student crisis caused a sharp, irrecoverable drop in overall enrollment, (b) domestic student demand continued its slow decline or accelerated, and (c) institutional countermeasures (lowering admissions standards, more aid, etc.) were insufficient to offset the twin shocks of demography and policy. The combination of a shrinking youth cohort, value skepticism, and especially the international enrollment collapse pushes the rate below the 26.6% threshold.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.yes_scenario: The Fall 2025 NCES data reports an enrollment rate above 26.6%. This occurs if the drop in international students, while severe, is proportionally smaller relative to the overall denominator (since international students are a minority of all 18-24-year-olds), and/or if colleges’ aggressive domestic recruitment fills enough seats to stabilize the rate. The drop in international enrollment may be offset by increased offers, fee waivers, and 'open door' admissions to domestic students, keeping the rate above the cutoff. Historical inertia and status quo bias work in favor of a slow decline, not an abrupt collapse.
Demographic Analysis (Population Project.final_reasoning: The key question is whether the 2025 four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds will drop by more than 10% from its 2015 baseline (29.9%), i.e., to ≤26.6%. Recent news is quite negative: a 17% drop in new international students following a 7% drop the prior year, a 44% drop in Indian arrivals, and overall international enrollment sentiment is at a low. Since international students are a small but significant share of four-year enrollments, this is a material negative shock. Domestically, demographic headwinds and declining perceived value are additional negatives. However, the denominator (all 18-24-year-olds) is also shrinking, which can partially offset the rate drop. Most importantly, the base rate of large, abrupt declines in this metric is low: declines are usually gradual. Even with the international student collapse, the total international student population is a small fraction of all 18-24-year-olds (1.2 million total international students across all levels; only a subset are in four-year undergraduate programs and within the 18-24 band). The combination of aggressive institutional countermeasures, historical inertia, and the low base rate for sharp aggregate declines makes it more likely than not that Caplan will win—but the probability is much lower than it would have been before the visa crisis. I estimate the chance that the 2025 rate is above 26.6% at 65%, reflecting a major negative shock but not enough, in my analysis, to drive the rate below the threshold in a single year.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.time_to_resolution: Data for 2025 enrollment rates will likely be released by NCES in late 2026, so approximately 12–18 months until public confirmation and bet resolution.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.perspective_relevance: As an expert in US social policy, with a focus on Pell Grants and student aid, I have deep insight into trends in US college access, financial aid, demographic shifts, and the policy and structural factors affecting college enrollment rates. This perspective is especially relevant given the current news on international student declines, domestic demographic changes, and the policy environment, all of which affect the numerator and denominator of the college enrollment rate.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.status_quo: Historically, the undergraduate enrollment rate for 18-24 year-olds in four-year colleges in the US has declined slowly but steadily since the early 2010s, but not at a pace fast enough to breach the 10% threshold Caplan's opponent needs. In 2015, the rate was 29.9%. A 10% drop would put the threshold at 26.6%. The rate for 2023 was around 27.2% (NCES Table 302.60), implying the most recent drop is relatively modest and the base rate is for a 'No' (Caplan wins) outcome.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic decline in US 18-24 year-olds ('enrollment cliff')
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability of Caplan winning, as the denominator shrinks and could amplify declines if the numerator (enrolled students) falls faster than the population.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Financial aid policy (Pell Grants, affordability)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability of Caplan winning, as expanded Pell Grant eligibility and aggressive tuition discounting by colleges (in response to enrollment pressure) help stabilize or even slightly boost enrollment among marginal students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Visa and international student crisis
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately decreases probability of Caplan winning, since international students make up a meaningful share of four-year college enrollment; a 17% drop in new international students—documented for 2025—could materially reduce the numerator.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perceived value of college and labor market alternatives
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability of Caplan winning, as growing skepticism about college ROI and the rise of alternatives (apprenticeships, certificate programs, direct employment) nudge more young adults out of the traditional four-year path.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Aggressive recruitment/admissions by colleges
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability of Caplan winning, as colleges are lowering barriers, waiving fees, offering direct admissions, financial incentives, and even extending deadlines to capture more students in an era of declining demand. This should act as a buttress against sharp declines.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal and state policy uncertainty, including research funding cuts and political climate
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability of Caplan winning, as uncertainty and negative headlines (especially regarding international students) may suppress enrollment, particularly at research universities and among foreign students.

US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.no_scenario: Despite a sharp drop in international students and a shrinking pool of domestic high school graduates, aggressive college recruitment, financial aid expansion, and the slow-moving nature of educational trends keep the 2025 enrollment rate at or above 26.7%. The rate dips only modestly from 2023's estimated 27.2%, perhaps ending up at 26.9%. Caplan wins, as the threshold is not breached.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.yes_scenario: The 2025 international student crisis, coupled with further domestic demographic decline, a persistent negative public perception of college value, and labor market anxiety, combine to produce the steepest single-year drop in recent history. The four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24-year-olds falls to 26.5% or below, narrowly causing Caplan to lose the bet.
US Social Policy (Pell Grant and Student.final_reasoning: The base rate and slow-moving nature of the US college enrollment rate are strong anchors; rarely do single-year or even multi-year swings exceed a percentage point or two, barring a crisis. The latest pre-2025 NCES data point (2023) is 27.2%, already close to the 26.6% threshold, but not yet there. The most recent news is unambiguously negative for enrollment: a 17% drop in new international students, visa delays, and a continued domestic headcount decline. However, two offsetting factors are crucial: (1) Aggressive and creative institutional recruitment/retention strategies are now being deployed at scale, which tends to blunt sharp downward trends; and (2) The denominator (total 18-24 year-olds) is also shrinking, which can 'soften' the impact on the percentage rate if the numerator doesn't fall as fast as it might appear. The international student drop is more impactful for overall headcount than for the 18-24 domestic cohort (the bet's denominator), as many international students are older (especially at the graduate level). Most international undergraduates are also concentrated at a relatively small number of institutions. While the 2025 news cycle is more negative than in past years, and a breach is more plausible than ever, the question asks whether the rate will fall 'more than 10%' from 2015—an unusually large drop in a single decade for such a slow-moving metric. On balance, I judge the likelihood that Caplan wins (i.e., enrollment remains above 26.6%) as slightly better than even, but much less certain than a year ago. An estimate of 60% reflects both the negative shock from international student declines and the stickiness of US enrollment rates, buttressed by aggressive institutional adaptation. I would adjust downward if further news emerges showing an unusual collapse in first-time domestic freshman enrollment in fall 2025.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).time_to_resolution: Approximately 12 months, as the question is about 2025 college enrollment rates and it is now December 2025. Resolution likely upon NCES data release in mid-2026 or Caplan's public announcement.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Economics (Human Capital Theory), I emphasize the demand for higher education as a function of its perceived return on investment versus opportunity cost, and the supply-side capacity of institutions to admit students. I focus on labor market signals, policy shocks (e.g., visa and funding), demographic pipeline, and alternative skill acquisition pathways. Human capital theory also helps to assess how shocks to the perceived value of college, or barriers for certain groups (like international students), affect enrollment rates.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).status_quo: In 2015, the fraction of American 18-24 year-olds enrolled in four-year colleges was 29.9%. The bet resolves YES if the rate in 2025 is above 26.6%. Historically, enrollment rates have declined gradually, but not precipitously; the base rate of a >10% drop over a decade is low in the absence of major shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic trends (shrinking cohort of 18-24 year-olds)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Fewer high school graduates due to demographic decline lowers the absolute and relative number of college enrollees.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic demand and perceived ROI of college
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Lower perceived value of a degree and growing skepticism (only 22% think it's worth it with loans) reduce domestic enrollment.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International student flows and visa policy shocks
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Catastrophic 2025 visa processing failure led to a 17% drop in new international enrollment, and overall international student numbers are falling (especially from China, with Indian numbers also down sharply).

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional adaptation (lowering admission barriers, financial aid, recruitment)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are actively adapting by lowering selectivity, waiving fees, offering direct/automatic admission, and boosting aid in order to fill seats, which may buffer against steeper declines.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Alternative pathways (work, apprenticeships, online credentials)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. As alternatives become more socially and economically viable, marginal students may opt out of traditional four-year college routes.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal and state funding cuts
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. Loss of funding can force program cuts and make some schools less attractive, but schools have strong incentives to maintain enrollment.

Economics (Human Capital Theory).no_scenario: A NO outcome (Caplan loses) occurs if the fraction of 18-24 year-olds enrolled in four-year colleges falls to 26.6% or below. Given recent data, this would likely require the combined effect of severe declines in both domestic and international enrollment (e.g., continued visa chaos, further drops in perceived value, and demographic decline), with institutional adaptations unable to fully offset these trends.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).yes_scenario: A YES outcome (Caplan wins) occurs if the enrollment rate remains above 26.6%. This would require that institutional adaptations—lowering barriers, increasing aid, aggressive recruitment—largely succeed in retaining enough students to buffer the drop, or that the domestic decline is less severe than anticipated and international numbers, while down, are not catastrophic. Even with negative headlines, the historical inertia of the sector and the slow-moving nature of cultural/structural shifts could keep rates just above the threshold.
Economics (Human Capital Theory).final_reasoning: The base rate favors inertia: historically, decade-scale drops of more than 10% in enrollment rates are rare without dramatic shocks. However, this cycle features a confluence of negative factors: a demographic trough, sharp and well-documented declines in new international enrollment (17% drop in 2025, especially acute for India and China), catastrophic visa processing failures, and a continued domestic decline in perceived value and ROI of college. However, schools are responding with unprecedented adaptations: waiving application fees, extending deadlines, offering automatic/direct admission, and increasing aid. These measures can only partially offset losses, particularly as international students (who are not easily replaced) account for a disproportionate share of four-year enrollments. My human capital perspective highlights that the marginal domestic student is more likely to opt out now than a decade ago. While the international enrollment collapse is damaging, not all international students are in the 18-24 age bracket, and some overall numbers are held up by increased graduate OPT participation. Given the magnitude of the international shock and the continuing domestic headwinds, but also considering historical inertia and institutional adaptation, I judge that the enrollment rate will likely come close to the 26.6% threshold, but is more likely than not to fall below it. However, the presence of strong institutional adaptation and the slow pace of change in higher education counsel against an extreme forecast. My estimate is that Caplan's probability of winning is modestly below 50%.

Economics (Signaling Theory).time_to_resolution: Approximately 12 months until NCES 2025 data is released and Bryan Caplan announces the outcome (expected mid-to-late 2026).
Economics (Signaling Theory).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Economics (Signaling Theory), my perspective is highly relevant because the value of college as a signaling device is central to enrollment trends. If degrees lose perceived signaling value due to changing labor market conditions or policy, rational students (and their families) will be less willing to enroll. Conversely, if alternatives to college (e.g., direct-to-work, certifications, apprenticeships) do not become more attractive or if the labor market continues to reward degrees, enrollment will remain robust. International student dynamics also matter, as foreign enrollments are often driven by the signaling value of a US degree in home labor markets.
Economics (Signaling Theory).status_quo: The status quo is that US four-year college enrollment rates among 18-24 year olds have declined only modestly since 2015, remaining above 26.6% through the post-pandemic period. Historically, such rates are sticky, changing slowly barring major shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International Student Enrollment Collapse
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The 17% drop in new international enrollments, visa delays, and perceptions of the US as unwelcoming are well-documented in recent news articles. Since international students are a non-trivial share of four-year enrollments (especially at public flagships and private universities), this sharply reduces the overall rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic Decline in 18-24 Year Old Population
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The US is experiencing a declining cohort size of college-age individuals, reducing the denominator for possible enrollees, which can drive down the enrollment rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Declining Perceived Value of College (Signaling Erosion)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Only 22% of Americans now believe a degree is worth the cost if financed by loans, and there is growing awareness of poor ROI in some majors. This weakens the signaling value of a degree, reducing demand for four-year college.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Colleges' Aggressive Recruitment and Lowered Barriers
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are responding with easier admissions, fee waivers, direct offers, and more financial aid to fill seats, which offsets some of the enrollment headwinds.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sticky Institutional/Status Quo Effects
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Enrollment rates tend to be slow-moving due to institutional inertia, family expectations, and the lack of widely accepted alternatives. A sudden >10% drop in 10 years would be historically unusual absent a major crisis.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Policy Shocks (Federal Funding Cuts, Visa Policy, Trump Administration)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The abrupt tightening of visa rules, funding cuts, and administrative disruption are shocks that can accelerate declines in both international and domestic enrollment.

Economics (Signaling Theory).no_scenario: International enrollment collapses further due to continued visa bottlenecks and unwelcoming policies; domestic enrollment continues to decline due to demographics and waning perceived value; efforts by colleges to boost enrollment are insufficient to overcome these headwinds, and the 2025 NCES data shows the rate drops to 26.6% or below.
Economics (Signaling Theory).yes_scenario: Colleges' aggressive recruitment and lowered barriers (easier admission, waived fees, more financial aid) are sufficient to keep enough students enrolled—including modest rebounds in international students via late policy corrections—so that the enrollment rate remains above 26.6%. The stickiness of the status quo (institutional inertia, slow-moving trends) prevails, and the rate is, for example, 27.1% in 2025.
Economics (Signaling Theory).final_reasoning: Base rates strongly favor slow change—large drops in four-year enrollment rates are rare, especially over a single decade. However, the 2025 news environment is substantially more negative than in prior years: the unprecedented 17% drop in new international students, a highly visible visa crisis, demographic decline, and sharply declining perceived value of college all point to significant downward pressure. While colleges have responded with aggressive recruitment tactics, the scale of international enrollment loss—combined with weak domestic demand—may be too large to fully offset. That said, some mitigating factors persist: international students are a minority of total enrollment, and the denominator (18-24 year olds) is also shrinking, which can partially offset the impact on the rate. Nonetheless, the signaling value of college has eroded, and policy shocks have been unusually severe in 2025. Given these factors, I judge the base rate (status quo holding) to be somewhat more likely than not, but with a much higher risk of a sharp drop than in previous years. I assign a substantial chance to a 'No' outcome but still see the most likely outcome as the rate remaining just above the threshold. Thus, the probability Caplan wins is slightly above even odds, but much less certain than a year ago.

Economics (Demographic Transition).time_to_resolution: About 1 year (question resolves when 2025 NCES data are published, likely late 2026, but the relevant data is for the 2025 academic year, which is essentially set in Fall 2025).
Economics (Demographic Transition).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Economics (Demographic Transition), I bring a deep understanding of how changing population structures (e.g., declining youth cohorts), labor market shifts, and international migration patterns affect higher education enrollment. I can contextualize recent shocks (visa delays, policy changes) within longstanding demographic and economic trends affecting college-going behaviors.
Economics (Demographic Transition).status_quo: The status quo, as of the 2015 baseline, was a 29.9% college enrollment rate among 18-24 year-olds in four-year institutions. As of pre-pandemic and early 2020s, this rate had been declining slowly, but not precipitously. Historically, such a sharp decline—to 26.6% or below (a >10% drop)—within a decade is rare for advanced economies unless precipitated by major shocks.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic transition: declining youth population
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The U.S. is experiencing a decline in the number of 18-year-olds, which puts downward pressure on total and proportional college enrollment, even if participation rates hold steady.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Structural value shift in higher education
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Widespread skepticism about the ROI of college, rising student debt, and alternative pathways (vocational training, direct-to-work, online credentials) erode the perceived value of a traditional four-year degree.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International student enrollment collapse (2024-2025)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The recent news of a 17% drop in new international students and visa chaos in 2025 is a sharp negative shock: international students disproportionately enroll in four-year institutions, and their share of total enrollment is nontrivial.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Colleges easing admissions, competing for students
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Institutions are counteracting lower demand by loosening standards, waiving fees, and offering financial aid. This 'open-door' approach acts as a buffer against sharper declines in enrollment rates.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Policy environment (Trump administration restrictions)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Stricter visa rules, erratic international student policy, and funding cuts create headwinds for four-year college enrollment, especially among non-citizens.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Base rate/historical stickiness of enrollment rates
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Historically, even with negative shocks, such a large drop (>10%) in a decade is unusual; enrollment rates tend to be sticky due to institutional inertia and cultural expectations.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Labor market softness and automation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but slightly increases probability. Economic downturns can sometimes push more young people into college due to weak job prospects, but automation and the changing labor market may deter those who do not see a degree as a ticket to stable employment.

Economics (Demographic Transition).no_scenario: International student enrollment collapses by more than 20% in 2025, domestic enrollment continues to slip as demographic headwinds bite, and financial pressures (plus skepticism about college value) push the four-year rate below 26.6%. Visa problems are not resolved in time for Fall 2025, and policy changes further deter both foreign and marginal domestic students.
Economics (Demographic Transition).yes_scenario: U.S. colleges aggressively recruit and admit more domestic students to compensate for international shortfalls, leveraging fee waivers and test-optional policies. The enrollment rate dips but only modestly, as demographic and value headwinds are cushioned by institutions' aggressive tactics and a soft labor market nudges some youth to college. The final 2025 four-year enrollment rate comes in slightly above 26.6%.
Economics (Demographic Transition).final_reasoning: The most recent news is sharply negative: the 2025 visa crisis caused a 17% drop in new international student enrollment—a substantial blow, as international students are a significant component of four-year college numbers. Domestic enrollment was already trending down due to demographic and value shifts, and the 'demographic cliff' is now in effect. Policy under the Trump administration is a further headwind. However, the base rate for a >10% drop over a decade is low, and colleges are taking extraordinary measures to keep seats filled, including drastically easing admissions. The most likely scenario is that the enrollment rate falls, but not quite enough to breach the 26.6% threshold. The negative international shock makes this a close call, but the underlying inertia and aggressive institutional responses suggest Caplan is still a modest favorite. I assign a 62% chance Caplan's side wins (enrollment rate >26.6%), with significant downside risk from the 2025 international student collapse.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).time_to_resolution: Approximately 12-18 months (the bet will resolve when 2025 NCES data is released, likely in late 2026, but the reference point is 2025 enrollment rates).
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).perspective_relevance: As an expert in Sociology with a focus on Status Attainment Research, I bring deep understanding of the structural dynamics that drive college enrollment, including the role of higher education as a signal for social mobility, the interplay of economic cycles with educational demand, demographic trends, and the effects of institutional policy shifts (such as admissions practices, financial aid, and international student flows). This perspective helps anchor predictions in base rates and the inertia of social structures, while being alert to genuine inflection points.
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).status_quo: The 18–24 year-old enrollment rate at four-year colleges in 2015 was 29.9%. The bet's threshold for Caplan to win is that the 2025 rate remains above 26.6% (i.e., no more than a 10% drop). Historically, the rate has been flat or declining slightly since the 2010 peak, but the pace has been gradual. The 2022 rate was around 27–28%.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic trends (declining US birthrates, fewer high school graduates)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Fewer 18–24 year-olds means less potential for absolute enrollment growth, increasing downward pressure on the rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic demand elasticity (perceived value of a four-year degree, cultural emphasis on college for status attainment)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed: Value skepticism could decrease demand, but status attainment norms and parental aspirations provide inertia, slowing declines.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International student enrollment (visa policy shocks in 2025, geopolitical headwinds)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: The 17% drop in new international students (especially from India and China) directly shrinks the enrollment numerator, with little short-term ability for colleges to offset losses domestically.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Colleges' institutional adaptation (lowering admissions barriers, more outreach, fee waivers, direct admissions)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability: Institutions are aggressively recruiting, making admissions easier, and extending offers to retain enrollment levels, which could buffer against sharper declines.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal and state policy environment (funding cuts, regulatory changes, Trump administration stance)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: Cuts and uncertainty may reduce capacity and perceived value, especially at public and research universities.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Economic context (labor market shifts, automation, debt aversion)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability: A weak job market and high debt can deter enrollment, though economic downturns sometimes drive more to college; however, automation narrative is pushing some away from traditional degrees.

Sociology (Status Attainment Research).no_scenario: The combined impact of a shrinking youth cohort, a severe and sudden drop in international student enrollment (especially post-2025 visa crisis), continued skepticism about the ROI of a college degree, and rising financial pressures push the 2025 four-year college enrollment rate for 18–24 year-olds below 26.6%. Colleges' mitigation efforts can't fully compensate, and the rate dips below the threshold (e.g., to 26.0–26.5%).
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).yes_scenario: Despite demographic headwinds and the international student drop, institutional scrambling (lowering admissions standards, aggressive recruitment, expanded financial aid, and direct admissions) stabilizes domestic enrollment. The decline in the enrollment rate is contained to less than 10% over the decade (e.g., 26.7–27.5%), allowing Caplan to win. The drop in international students is partially offset by increased domestic uptake among marginal students drawn in by easier admissions and aid.
Sociology (Status Attainment Research).final_reasoning: The base rate for year-over-year declines in US college enrollment is slow, with sharp drops historically rare outside of major external shocks (e.g., COVID-19). However, 2025 presents a confluence of negative shocks: a catastrophic visa processing failure causing a 17% drop in new international students, a 17% drop in Chinese students, and a 44.5% drop in new Indian arrivals. International students are disproportionately enrolled in four-year institutions—often elite ones—but their numbers also buoy the overall enrollment denominator. At the same time, the domestic pool of 18–24 year-olds is shrinking due to demographic trends, and skepticism about degree value is rising. On the other hand, colleges are responding with aggressive admissions reforms, lowering barriers, and offering more aid to stabilize enrollment. Given the inertia in status attainment norms and the likelihood that institutions will squeeze out marginal gains domestically, I expect the four-year rate to fall, but not in a cliff-like fashion. The 2022 rate was around 27–28%. Factoring in a possible 0.5–1 percentage point drop from the international student crisis and domestic headwinds, the risk of dipping below 26.6% is real but still just below even odds. The inertia of the system and institutional adaptations suggest a modestly higher chance of Caplan barely winning his bet, but the risk of a sharp drop is substantially higher than in prior years. My forecast: 57%.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).time_to_resolution: Data likely to be published in late 2026, so approximately 11-13 months until final NCES release and Caplan's public statement.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).perspective_relevance: As a sociologist specializing in Social Stratification Theory, I focus on how educational access, class, race, and international migration patterns shape participation in higher education. This perspective is critical because college enrollment rates are not only a function of aggregate demand but are deeply shaped by structural inequalities, institutional incentives, and global flows of students—especially as stratification processes adapt to policy shocks, labor market shifts, and perceptions of value.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).status_quo: The 18-24 year-old four-year college enrollment rate in the US has been trending downward since its 2010 peak, but had only dropped about 8-9% by 2023. The 2025 threshold (Caplan's win) is 26.6%, compared to a 2015 baseline of 29.9%. In the absence of major shocks, a slow decline would be expected, but not necessarily enough to push below the 26.6% threshold by 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Collapse in new international student enrollment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability. The 17% drop in new international students (for Fall 2025), attributed to visa delays, policy crackdowns, and anti-immigrant rhetoric, is unprecedented. International students disproportionately enroll in four-year colleges (often elite ones), pay full tuition, and have been a key 'pressure release' for overall enrollment as domestic demand has stagnated. This sudden contraction deals a major blow to the denominator sustaining the 18-24 four-year enrollment rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Demographic decline of US 18-24 year-olds
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. The US is entering a demographic trough, with fewer high school graduates due to lower birth rates in the late 2000s and 2010s, reinforcing downward pressure on potential college entrants.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Increased institutional efforts to admit marginal domestic students
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. Colleges have reacted to falling applicant pools by waiving fees, lowering standards, offering automatic admission, and extending deadlines—behavior predicted by stratification theory as institutions adapt to revenue threats. These 'open door' policies may temporarily prop up enrollment rates at the margin, especially among domestic students from lower strata.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Lowered perceived value of college degrees, rising costs and debt aversion
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Only 22% of Americans believe a degree is worth the cost if financed with debt; high-ROI STEM fields remain attractive, but non-selective and non-STEM programs are increasingly seen as poor investments. This drives more young people to forgo four-year college, especially among lower- and middle-class students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Federal funding cuts and institutional financial pressure
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. With multi-billion dollar research cuts and declining tuition revenue, especially among private nonprofit colleges, some institutions may shrink class sizes, close programs, or even shutter, further reducing available seats.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: K-shaped recovery and economic polarization
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Mixed effect. The upper class continues to send children to college for credentialing and social capital, but the lower class faces growing obstacles—cost, uncertain returns, and job market pressure. The net effect likely decreases probability, as stratification hardens and overall enrollment falls.

Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).no_scenario: International student enrollment collapses further (down >15%), domestic enrollment fails to compensate due to demography and value skepticism, and funding cuts force some colleges to reduce capacity. The NCES data for 2025 shows the 18-24 year-old four-year enrollment rate falling below 26.6%, and Caplan loses the bet.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).yes_scenario: Despite the international student crisis, colleges' aggressive recruitment and open admissions policies succeed in offsetting most losses, perhaps aided by a short-term uptick in domestic enrollment from students seeking insulation from a poor labor market. The rate stays above 26.6% (e.g., 27.1%), and Caplan wins.
Sociology (Social Stratification Theory).final_reasoning: The status quo trajectory before 2024 suggested a slow decline in four-year college enrollment, but not enough to fall below the 26.6% threshold by 2025. However, the 2025 news indicates a dramatic, unprecedented 17% drop in new international student enrollment, especially from key countries like India (down 44.5% in August 2025). Given that international students have been a major buffer for four-year college numbers and that US domestic demand is flat or declining, this represents a structural shock. Additional headwinds include demographic decline, skepticism about college value, and federal funding cuts. Colleges are trying to offset this with easier admissions and fee waivers, but these are unlikely to fully compensate given the magnitude of international losses and broader economic/political headwinds. Stratification theory predicts that less privileged groups will be disproportionately deterred by cost and risk, making a sharp recovery in domestic enrollment improbable. Given these factors, the likelihood that the rate remains above 26.6% is less than even, but not negligible—there is still some potential for a marginal buffer effect. I estimate the probability that Caplan wins (rate >26.6%) at 35%, with most weight on a 'No' outcome.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.time_to_resolution: Approximately 11-13 months (2025 data typically published in late 2026, but preliminary figures and Caplan's public statement may resolve the bet sooner, likely within a year).
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Education Studies, especially Tinto's Student Integration theory, my perspective emphasizes the social, academic, and institutional integration factors that drive student enrollment and persistence. This lens is particularly relevant because it contextualizes enrollment trends not just in economic or policy shocks, but in terms of student belonging, perceived value, and institutional responses—crucial for interpreting the likely magnitude and durability of enrollment shifts, especially for traditional four-year colleges.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.status_quo: The rate of 18-24 year-olds enrolled in four-year colleges has been declining slowly, but as of 2015 was 29.9%. A decline of 10% or more (to 26.6% or lower) would require a sustained, substantial drop. Historically, even during periods of economic or social turbulence, such sharp declines have been rare over a decade.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International Student Enrollment Collapse
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Strongly decreases probability of Caplan winning. Recent news indicates a 17% YoY drop in new international students, the steepest decline in years, driven by visa processing failures and unwelcoming policies. International students comprise a significant share of four-year college enrollment, especially among 18-24 year-olds, and are crucial to institutional finances.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Domestic Demographic Decline
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. The shrinking pool of 18-year-olds (projected to decline over the next 15 years) is a structural headwind, leading colleges to compete harder for applicants, but overall supply is falling.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Enrollment Rate Base Rate & Institutional Adaptation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Moderately increases probability. The status quo is sticky: even in periods of crisis, four-year college enrollment rates for 18-24 year-olds tend to decline gradually, not in sharp drops. Institutional adaptation (e.g., easier admissions, fee waivers, increased financial aid) partly offsets headwinds.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Perceived Value of College & Student Integration
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Skepticism about ROI, low graduation rates, and the declining sense of college as a pathway to upward mobility (especially for students from marginalized backgrounds) undercut Tinto's integration drivers, making it harder to attract and retain students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Pandemic & Economic Factors
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly decreases probability. Lingering effects from COVID (lost momentum in enrollment, increased alternative pathways) and current economic uncertainty (wage stagnation, layoffs, rising debt delinquencies) may deter some would-be students.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional Financial Pressures
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but slightly increases probability. Financially stressed colleges are lowering standards and increasing incentives to sustain enrollment, which may cushion the aggregate rate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Recent Data Trajectory (Pre-2025)
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Ambiguous, but suggests risk. Data indicate an 8.4% aggregate enrollment drop since 2010; with accelerating losses in 2024-2025, the possibility of a rapid approach to the 26.6% threshold is real, but not certain.

Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.no_scenario: Visa processing failures persist through the 2025 cycle, causing another 10-15% drop in new international students (on top of this year's 17% decline), while domestic enrollment continues to shrink due to demographics and skepticism about value. Even aggressive institutional countermeasures cannot fully compensate. The cumulative effect is a drop in the four-year college enrollment rate for 18-24 year-olds to 26.6% or below in the 2025 NCES data.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.yes_scenario: The 2025 international enrollment crisis proves a one-off: emergency fixes restore visa processing for Spring and Fall 2026, stemming further losses. Domestic enrollment stabilizes at most institutions due to aggressive recruitment, fee waivers, and financial aid. The overall drop from 2015 to 2025 is substantial, but stops just short of the 10% threshold, with the 2025 rate reported at 26.7%-28%. Caplan wins, albeit narrowly.
Education Studies (Tinto Student Integra.final_reasoning: The base rate for decade-long, 10%+ drops in four-year college enrollment among 18-24 year-olds is low: historically, enrollment rates have declined gradually, even amid shocks. However, this cycle is different—2025 saw a catastrophic 17% drop in new international students, and domestic enrollment is shrinking due to demographics and eroding perceived value. The unique Tinto perspective underscores that the integration of students is being undermined not just by policy and economics, but by a crisis of belonging and utility. Still, most institutions are fighting hard to fill seats, and overall numbers are somewhat buffered by students extending time-to-degree and increased efforts at recruitment. The question is whether the cumulative decline from 29.9% (2015) to 2025 will breach the 26.6% threshold. The evidence suggests we are dangerously close to that line, with a real risk of overshooting, especially if international enrollment does not recover quickly. However, the resilience of the status quo and institutional adaptability make a sub-26.6% figure slightly less likely than not. My probability thus reflects high risk for Caplan, but not quite an even bet—there remains a modest edge for him winning.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.time_to_resolution: Approximately 1 year (the bet resolves when NCES 2025 enrollment data is published, likely in late 2026, but the reference is the 2025 data).
Education Studies (Access and Participat.perspective_relevance: As an expert in Education Studies (Access and Participation Research), I focus on the drivers of postsecondary enrollment, including demographic, economic, policy, and institutional factors. My expertise is particularly relevant to understanding the nuanced effects of access barriers (like visa policy), shifts in college-going behavior, and institutional responses to enrollment pressures, which are all crucial for accurately forecasting marginal changes near the 26.6% threshold.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.status_quo: The most recent (pre-2025) college enrollment rates for 18-24-year-olds in four-year institutions in the US have been gradually declining, but remained above 26.6% for the past decade. The 2015 baseline was 29.9%. Historically, year-to-year declines have been modest, and the rate had not dropped below 26.6% in any recent year prior to this bet's resolution window.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Sharp Decline in International Student Enrollment in 2025
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. News reports a 17% drop in new international student enrollment for 2025, largely due to catastrophic visa processing issues. International undergraduates are a significant share of four-year college cohorts (particularly at public flagships and elite privates), and such a sudden drop is unprecedented. While overall international students are a minority, their concentrated effect on four-year enrollment is non-trivial and could move the needle, especially as domestic numbers stagnate.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Continued Declines in Domestic Enrollment
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. US domestic enrollment has been trending downward due to demographic decline in the number of high school graduates (the so-called 'demographic cliff'), declining perceived value of college, and persistent cost barriers. The news confirms an 8.4% decline since 2010 and stagnant/negative sentiment about college value, especially for non-STEM majors.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Institutional Aggressiveness to Fill Seats
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability. Colleges are responding with easier admissions (fee waivers, one-click apps, auto-admit, extended deadlines), more financial aid, and aggressive recruitment. This institutional elasticity may cushion the overall enrollment rate, especially as colleges lower standards and pursue nontraditional and transfer students more actively.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: International Enrollment Drop Partly Offset by OPT and Graduate Retention
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Neutral to slightly increases probability. While new international undergraduate enrollment is down, total international enrollment is somewhat buffered by graduate students and OPT (Optional Practical Training), who may remain counted in the college population. However, this is more relevant for overall international numbers than for the 18-24 undergrad cohort.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Visa/Policy Environment and Perceived Hostility
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Decreases probability. Beyond technical processing issues, the cumulative policy hostility, negative sentiment, and competition from other countries (UK, Canada, Australia, Germany) are driving a shift in international student flows. This is likely to have an outsized effect in 2025, compounding the acute administrative failures.

perspective_derived_factors.factor: Lagged Effects, Data Definitions, and Institutional Adaptation
perspective_derived_factors.effect: Slightly increases probability. The NCES data may reflect enrollments as of fall 2025, and institutions may have taken emergency steps to admit last-minute students, extend offers, or promote transfer/part-time conversions to full-time status to shore up numbers. There is also some uncertainty as to whether all the international drop will be felt in the 18-24, four-year college cohort, or whether some of the loss is at the graduate level.

Education Studies (Access and Participat.no_scenario: Despite institutional efforts, the compounded effects of a sharp drop in new international undergraduates (especially from India and China), continued domestic softness due to population and value concerns, and the lack of a strong economic rebound cause the 18-24-year-old four-year college enrollment rate to fall below 26.6% in 2025. The decline is most pronounced at non-elite publics and less-selective privates, which cannot fill seats despite relaxed admissions. The NCES data, reflecting these trends, settles below the critical threshold.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.yes_scenario: Colleges succeed in offsetting international losses through aggressive domestic recruitment, relaxed standards, and expanded financial aid. Some international students defer but enroll later in the cycle (just enough to keep numbers up), and colleges convert more part-time and transfer students to full-time status in the 18-24 age band. The overall erosion is modest, and the enrollment rate in NCES data remains just above 26.6%, allowing Caplan to win.
Education Studies (Access and Participat.final_reasoning: The sharp, well-documented drop in new international undergrad enrollment for 2025, combined with ongoing domestic demographic and attitudinal headwinds, represents a significant one-time negative shock. The size of the international drop (17% new, with Indian arrivals down >40%) is large enough to plausibly push the overall 18-24 four-year enrollment rate below 26.6%, given that the margin in recent years was not large. While institutional adaptability (relaxed standards, aggressive recruitment) provides some buffer—and there is a possibility of last-minute enrollments or definitional quirks slightly boosting the rate—the scale and timing of the international crisis, coupled with stagnant or declining domestic interest, makes a drop below 26.6% more likely than not. However, because the base rate for a precipitous drop of this magnitude is low, and institutional self-preservation is strong, I do not assign extremely high confidence; this is a close call. But weighing the evidence, I judge that a 'No' outcome (Caplan loses) is now the likelier scenario.
